bug.author: r-wheeler
bug.description:
According to the numpy dtype docs, numpy.unicode_ is equivalent to pythons built in unicode type (<denchmark-link:https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/arrays.dtypes.html>https://docs.scipy.org/doc/numpy/reference/arrays.dtypes.html</denchmark-link> ) , however when trying to do something like the following <denchmark-code>c = np.atleast_1d(u'this test') [d for d in parser.pipe(c)] </denchmark-code>
Results in: TypeError: Argument 'string' has incorrect type (expected unicode, got numpy.unicode_) If you're looking for help with your code, consider posting a question on StackOverflow instead: <denchmark-link:http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/spacy>http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/spacy</denchmark-link> --> <denchmark-h:h2>Your Environment</denchmark-h>
Python version: 2.7.13 Platform: Darwin-16.6.0-x86_64-i386-64bit spaCy version: 1.8.2 Installed models: en

comments.comment: Hmm, I'd hoped to make this work with a Cython fused type, but it seems numpy doesn't offer a type definition for its unicode_ type. I could add a type conversion on the API boundary, for pipe, __call__, etc. I'm not sure this is a great solution. Can you just call unicode on the text before passing it to spaCy?

The text is already unicode. It looks like the real issue is np.array can not be used as a drop in replacement container for built in list ie parser.pipe(np.array(["test this"])) Solution was to just call .tolist on the ndarray
This thread has been automatically locked since there has not been any recent activity after it was closed. Please open a new issue for related bugs.
